home.hadithText1: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "A good dream is from Allah, and a bad dream is from Satan. So if anyone of you has a dream which he dislikes, he should spit on his left side thrice and seek refuge with Allah from Satan, for it will not harm him."
home.hadithText2: He also said: "A true dream is one of the forty-six parts of Prophethood."
home.hadithText3: He also said: "Those of you who have the truest dreams are those who are most truthful in speech."

propheticGuidance.mainTitle: Prophetic Guidance on Dreams and Visions

content.text: When the Prophet ﷺ finished the Morning Prayer, he would turn to them (his companions) and ask: "Did any of you see a dream last night?"

This hadith indicates the honor and virtue of the science of dream interpretation, because the Prophet ﷺ used to ask about them to teach his companions how to interpret them. Allah praised Joseph (peace be upon him) by establishing him in the land and teaching him the interpretation of narrations, which has been interpreted as the interpretation of dreams. Joseph ﷺ was the most knowledgeable in that, as was our Prophet ﷺ. Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq was among the best interpreters, followed by Ibn Sirin and Sa'id ibn al-Musayyib.
content.author: Imam Ibn Abd al-Barr

section3.title: Imam Nawawi's Directives on Dream Interpretation

content.text: From An-Nawawi's commentary on the Hadith:

items: It is recommended for the Imam to turn to his companions after the salam to ask them about dreams.
It is preferable to hasten the interpretation in the morning because the mind is clear.
It is permissible to discuss knowledge and dream interpretation after Fajr prayer.
It is permissible to turn one's back to the Qibla for the purpose of knowledge or discussion after prayer.

content.text: Whoever claims to have seen a dream he did not see will be ordered to tie two barley grains together, and he will never be able to do it...
content.narrator: Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him)

content.text: One of the greatest lies is to claim to have seen what one has not seen.
content.narrator: Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with him)

section5.title: At-Tabari's Commentary on Lying About Dreams

content.text: The severe warning against lying about dreams is because it involves fabricating a lie against Allah, claiming He showed him what He did not. Lying against Allah is greater than lying against people. Even if lying in wakefulness might lead to false testimony in matters of life or property, lying in a dream is a direct fabrication against Allah Almighty.
content.author: Imam At-Tabari
